articles.headline: High Speed for the Sparsely Wired
articles.snippet: A $7.2 billion federal stimulus package will help extend high-speed access to more poor and rural sections of the United States.
articles.abstract: A $7.2 billion federal stimulus package will help extend high-speed access to more poor and rural sections of the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Government stimulus spending is a contentious issue right now in Washington. But the $7.2 billion in the last stimulus package for extending high-speed Internet access is just beginning to be spent, and the beneficiaries could not be happier.

articles.headline: ‘Daddy, Are We Rich?’ and Other Tough Questions
articles.snippet: Children can say the darnedest things, but when they start asking financial questions, it’s best to be prepared.
articles.abstract: Children can say the darnedest things, but when they start asking financial questions, it’s best to be prepared.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is nothing like an inquisitive child to make you realize just how complicated the topic of money is. That’s what I ended up thinking after my 4-year-old daughter a few weeks ago stomped her feet, turned red and demanded to know why we did not own a summer house.

articles.headline: Stars, Cameras and Theatrics Strain Courts
articles.snippet: The Los Angeles court system is struggling with a growing number of celebrities in need of adjudication.
articles.abstract: The Los Angeles court system is struggling with a growing number of celebrities in need of adjudication.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  What price (celebrity) justice?

articles.headline: New Rules May Cloud the Outlook for Biomass
articles.snippet: In Massachusetts and elsewhere, environmentalists are questioning the clean and renewable energy claims made by developers of biomass power.
articles.abstract: In Massachusetts and elsewhere, environmentalists are questioning the clean and renewable energy claims made by developers of biomass power.
articles.lead_paragraph: An energy technology that has long been viewed as a clean and climate-friendly alternative to fossil fuels is facing tough new regulatory hurdles that could ultimately hamper its ability to compete with renewable power sources like wind and solar.

articles.headline: U.S. Widens Tax Inquiry Into HSBC
articles.snippet: Prosecutors are looking into whether “there’s a UBS-style situation of a bank actively marketing” tax evasion services, said a person briefed on the proceedings.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors are looking into whether “there’s a UBS-style situation of a bank actively marketing” tax evasion services, said a person briefed on the proceedings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are ramping up their criminal investigation into HSBC concerning its sale of offshore tax services to wealthy Americans suspected of evading taxes, according to two people briefed on the matter and to court papers.

articles.headline: In India, Castes, Honor and Killings Intertwine
articles.snippet: A woman’s death and the arrest of her mother have drawn attention to a resurgence of so-called honor killings.
articles.abstract: A woman’s death and the arrest of her mother have drawn attention to a resurgence of so-called honor killings.
articles.lead_paragraph: KODERMA, India  When Nirupama Pathak left this remote mining region for graduate school in New Delhi, she seemed to be leaving the old India for the new. Her parents paid her tuition and did not resist when she wanted to choose her own career. But choosing a husband was another matter.

articles.headline: Illegal Workers Swept From Jobs in ‘Silent Raids’
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has started sending federal agents to audit records of thousands of companies, forcing businesses to fire every illegal immigrant.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has started sending federal agents to audit records of thousands of companies, forcing businesses to fire every illegal immigrant.
articles.lead_paragraph: BREWSTER, Wash.  The Obama administration has replaced immigration raids at factories and farms with a quieter enforcement strategy: sending federal agents to scour companies’ records for illegal immigrant workers.

articles.headline: Wall St. Hiring in Anticipation of an Economic Recovery
articles.snippet: While much of the country remains fixated on the bleak employment picture, hiring is beginning to pick up in the place that led the economy into recession.
articles.abstract: While much of the country remains fixated on the bleak employment picture, hiring is beginning to pick up in the place that led the economy into recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: While much of the country remains fixated on the bleak employment picture, hiring is beginning to pick up in the place that led the economy into recession  Wall Street.

articles.headline: Volcker Pushes for Reform, Regretting Past Silence
articles.snippet: Despite his efforts on financial legislation aiming to correct years of deregulation, Paul Volcker is concerned that banks will still have too much wiggle room.
articles.abstract: Despite his efforts on financial legislation aiming to correct years of deregulation, Paul Volcker is concerned that banks will still have too much wiggle room.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST before the Fourth of July weekend, Paul A. Volcker packed his fishing gear and set off for his annual outing to the Canadian wilds to cast for Atlantic salmon.

articles.headline: Mortgage Investors Turn to State Courts for Relief
articles.snippet: Aiming to recover losses in the housing crisis, buyers of soured mortgage-backed securities are using state law to sue big banks.
articles.abstract: Aiming to recover losses in the housing crisis, buyers of soured mortgage-backed securities are using state law to sue big banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: INVESTORS who lost billions on boatloads of faulty mortgage securities have had a hard time holding Wall Street accountable for selling the things in the first place.

articles.headline: Factory Efficiency Comes to the Hospital
articles.snippet: Seattle Children’s Hospital says it has improved patient care, and its bottom line, by incorporating practices made famous in manufacturing.
articles.abstract: Seattle Children’s Hospital says it has improved patient care, and its bottom line, by incorporating practices made famous in manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE

articles.headline: In Haiti, the Displaced Are Left Clinging to the Edge
articles.snippet: Six months after an earthquake, only 28,000 of 1.5 million displaced Haitians have new homes, and Port-au-Prince remains a tableau of life in the ruins.
articles.abstract: Six months after an earthquake, only 28,000 of 1.5 million displaced Haitians have new homes, and Port-au-Prince remains a tableau of life in the ruins.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Hundreds of displaced families live perilously in a single file of flimsy shanties planted along the median strip of a heavily congested coastal road here called the Route des Rails.

articles.headline: Bank Bailout Is Potent Issue for Fall Elections
articles.snippet: Lawmakers who backed the Troubled Asset Relief Program to rescue the banking system in 2008 are haunted by the vote.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers who backed the Troubled Asset Relief Program to rescue the banking system in 2008 are haunted by the vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The vote in 2008 to bail out Wall Street was framed as the only way to avert an economic meltdown and relieve financial institutions of their most poisonous holdings. For many members of Congress, it turns out that the vote itself was toxic.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Investors Expect Profits and Seek Clues to Future
articles.snippet: Many Americans are still waiting for an economic recovery. But for corporate America, a recovery of sorts is already at hand.
articles.abstract: Many Americans are still waiting for an economic recovery. But for corporate America, a recovery of sorts is already at hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many Americans are still waiting for an economic recovery. But for corporate America, a recovery of sorts is already at hand.

articles.headline: Distrust Slows U.S. Training of Pakistanis
articles.snippet: The American-led training program is part of an effort to repair relations with the Pakistani military, government and public.
articles.abstract: The American-led training program is part of an effort to repair relations with the Pakistani military, government and public.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAK, Pakistan  The recent graduation ceremony here for Pakistani troops trained by Americans to fight the Taliban and Al Qaeda was intended as show of fresh cooperation between the Pakistani and American militaries. But it said as much about its limitations.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: End of Census, and for Many, End of Job
articles.snippet: The Census Bureau is shedding hundreds of thousands of positions, sending workers into a daunting job market.
articles.abstract: The Census Bureau is shedding hundreds of thousands of positions, sending workers into a daunting job market.
articles.lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  It was a finely honed machine, this United States Census team, and it had a good run. But in the coming days and weeks, many of its members will experience the pain of unemployment  once again.

articles.headline: BP Is Said to Explore Asset Sale
articles.snippet: A possible deal with Apache would include stakes in BP’s Alaska oil fields, for $10 billion to $12 billion.
articles.abstract: A possible deal with Apache would include stakes in BP’s Alaska oil fields, for $10 billion to $12 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: BP is in talks to sell assets, including stakes in its Alaska oil fields, to Apache for $10 billion to $12 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Governors Voice Grave Concerns on Immigration
articles.snippet: Democratic governors said they worried that the suit against Arizona’s law could cost the party in the elections.
articles.abstract: Democratic governors said they worried that the suit against Arizona’s law could cost the party in the elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In a private meeting with White House officials this weekend, Democratic governors voiced deep anxiety about the Obama administration’s suit against Arizona’s new immigration law, worrying that it could cost a vulnerable Democratic Party in the fall elections.

articles.headline: Divining the Return on a Candidate’s Investment
articles.snippet: A Republican strategist got $1 million for his movie company from Meg Whitman and later joined her campaign.
articles.abstract: A Republican strategist got $1 million for his movie company from Meg Whitman and later joined her campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first blush, the 19 pages of financial disclosures that Meg Whitman filed earlier this year for her run for governor of California are a humdrum blur of ordinary, if sizable, investments  until one for more than $1 million in an “entertainment/production” company called “Tools Down! Productions.”

articles.headline: Forget Shhh! Theaters Want You to Sing Along
articles.snippet: Studios are hoping that younger audiences will return to theaters for events like a “Grease” sing-along.
articles.abstract: Studios are hoping that younger audiences will return to theaters for events like a “Grease” sing-along.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  They came dressed as Pink Ladies and Beauty School Dropouts. They cheered Danny Zuko at Thunder Road. The rama-lama ding-donging? Deafening.

articles.headline: A Web Site That’s Not Afraid to Pick a Fight
articles.snippet: In its usual controversial tone, Jezebel, a blog for women, garnered more than 211,000 page views on a post calling “The Daily Show” sexist.
articles.abstract: In its usual controversial tone, Jezebel, a blog for women, garnered more than 211,000 page views on a post calling “The Daily Show” sexist.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jon Stewart announced on the June 29 episode of “The Daily Show” that “Jezebel thinks I’m a sexist,” some viewers may have been wondering: who exactly is Jezebel?

articles.headline: Techmeme Offers Tech News at Internet Speed
articles.snippet: Techmeme uses algorithms to constantly find the latest tech news, and has added a human editor too.
articles.abstract: Techmeme uses algorithms to constantly find the latest tech news, and has added a human editor too.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — News lovers in Washington can’t live without Mike Allen at Politico. Hollywood squabbles over the relative merits of Sharon Waxman’s TheWrap versus Nikki Finke’s Deadline. The newspaper industry reads the news collected by Jim Romenesko.

articles.headline: High Fashion Relents to Web’s Pull
articles.snippet: Luxury brands were slow to embrace the Web, but the recession has changed their thinking.
articles.abstract: Luxury brands were slow to embrace the Web, but the recession has changed their thinking.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Web site for Marc Jacobs, the flamboyant fashion designer with an estimated $5 billion brand, has many things: stylish videos of employees describing their jobs, footage from elite fashion shows and parties, and even a photo of the company’s president staring down a camel in Egypt.

articles.headline: In Cable Delivery, Rivals Are Pouncing
articles.snippet: Verizon’s play for subscribers is fresh evidence that cable giants like Time Warner are under increasing pressure.
articles.abstract: Verizon’s play for subscribers is fresh evidence that cable giants like Time Warner are under increasing pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Unlike the bitter disputes that have broken out between TV networks and cable operators  Fox versus Time Warner Cable, ABC versus Cablevision  the latest round of fee negotiations between the Walt Disney Company and Time Warner have, so far, been quite amicable.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Brian Stelter
